learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate high-level clinical skills within the scope of practice of the specialist dental disciplines in a clinical and simulated environment.
Appraise complex patient histories to diagnose and treatment plan conditions commonly managed within the specialist dental disciplines.
Evaluate clinical reasoning and clinical judgement skills in care planning in specialist dental disciplines.
Analyse oral care plans used to manage individuals diagnosed with complex conditions commonly managed within the specialist dental disciplines.
Demonstrate advanced competency in clinical procedures for a range of specialist dental disciplines in a simulated and clinical environment.
Appraise scientific evidence to justify material and medicament selection in procedures conducted in a clinical and simulated environment.
Demonstrate effective, accurate and responsible verbal and written communication, including electronic patient records, with patients, carers, clinical and supervisory staff and peers.
Apply contemporary principles of infection control to consistently maintain a safe working environment.
Reflect critically on experiential learning, feedback and how evidence-based practice is applied in clinical environments.
Develop processes for seeking advice and scientific evidence to meet gaps in knowledge, understanding and clinical ability.

assessments.task_description:
In this task, you will be required to provide a critique for a series of stimulus items (radiographs, images, videos, etc.) that show cases and examples of dental practice related to complex patient histories, diagnosis and treatment plans, material and medicament selection and infection control. Your critique of the work you see in the stimulus should be based on your knowledge and understanding of best practice in complex patient histories, diagnosis and treatment plans, material and medicament selection and infection control.  

First submissions to peer, revision of a peer’s work and then final submission to the course coordinator is through your ePortfolio.  

Part A: Submit a draft critique to a peer for feedback with a request for specific feedback. 

Part B: Review peer feedback and update draft. Upload final version and complete a short reflection on what you learned about your work after reviewing the work of your peer and consequently, what you improved and why. Your final submission includes your final version and your peer’s draft which contains your feedback.

assessments.task_description:
For further information, including instructions for each part and specific due dates, please see the Blackboard Task Sheet for this assessment item.

In this task, students are required to complete and submit a Clinical Practice Portfolio over the course of the semester, in order to document clinical performance within the patient clinic. Students must complete the portfolio for ALL clinical, dental assisting, fail to attend, and observational sessions. It consists of multiple ‘parts’ that all contribute to an overall ‘Pass’ or ‘Fail’ for the assessment at the end of the semester.

This is a hurdle requirement and must be passed to progress throughout the Doctor of Dental Medicine for all clinical-based courses in the program.


To achieve a pass, the following conditions must be met:


Part 1: Clinical learning plan

This part of the portfolio is due at 5pm on the Friday of the first week of semester. Submit the completed form to the Course Coordinator via ePortfolio.

This component includes three guided parts: 1. A course overview, 2. Case planning, and 3. A feedback summary.

This form helps set focused clinical learning goals for the semester. It also provides an opportunity to reflect on previous feedback and identify actions for improving clinical performance.


Part 2: Mid-semester portfolio review

All three components are submitted to the Course Coordinator by 5pm Monday, the first day back after the in-semester break.

This component includes three parts: 1. A well-being check, 2. Case tallies (with a de-identified Patient Management System Treatment Report uploaded), and 3. A self-evaluation of clinical performance so far throughout the semester.

This mid-semester task supports development as a reflective, self-directed learner and prepares you for a feedback meeting with the lead dentist in the UQ Herston Dental Clinic (Clinic 2.1).


Part 3: End-of-semester portfolio review and case tallies

Submit both components to your Course Coordinator by 5pm Friday of the last week of semester via ePortfolio.

This component includes two parts: 1. Case tallies for the semester (with a de-identified Patient Management System Treatment Report uploaded), and 2. An End-of-semester Reflection and Feedback Form.

This task helps to reflect on clinical progress, feedback integration, and future growth.


Course-specific session sign-off forms (submitted after each clinical session)

These forms are essential for tracking performance and must be completed at the end of every AM or PM session where you see a patient. If no patient was seen, submit the Dental Assisting/FTA form instead.

Your session form is submitted to, and assessed by, your Clinical Educator and includes:

·       Clinical performance (all sessions)

·       Discipline-specific performance (only if you performed relevant procedures)

·       Fitness to practise (must pass; assessed as EM or ENM only. If you receive an ENM in this category, you will receive an ENM as your overall grade for the session.)


Student marking expectations for each semester are calibrated to your year and stage in the DMD program. You are not being marked against the performance of a fully qualified dentist (4.0 standard), but rather according to where you should be for your level of clinical training. Clinical educators will adjust their marking expectations accordingly as you progress throughout the program.


Overall session grade categories

The only weighted grade for each session is the ‘Overall Grade’ that are assigned the following values:

·       0= Expectations Not Met (ENM) = <50%

·       2= Developing (D) = 50 to <69%

·       3= Expectations Met (EM) = 69-<88%

·       4= Exceeds Expectations = 88-100%


Minimum performance requirement:

The pass requirements are based on the DMD Year Level and Semester level, where the average overall score must be a minimum of:

DMD Year 2, Summer Semester ≥ 2.5/4.0 (~62.5%)

DMD Year 2, Semester 1 ≥ 2.8/4.0 (~70%)

DMD Year 2, Semester 2 ≥ 2.8/4.0 (~70%)

DMD Year 3, Semester 1 ≥ 3.0/4.0 (~75%)

DMD Year 3, Semester 2 ≥ 3.0/4.0 (~75%)

DMD Year 4, Semester 1 ≥ 3.2/4.0 (~80%)

In accordance with PPL Assessment Procedure Section 3 Part J, supplementary assessment will NOT be available for clinical practice performance (portfolio) as professional competencies are developed over a 16 week practicum. There is NO resubmission or resit option available for this assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Log of clinical experience

Students must complete a specified log of clinical experience for their clinical work as an operator. These are used both to provide formative feedback to students on their clinical progress, as well as to record and collate specific details of the volumes and types of treatments undertaken. For the various clinical disciplines, the case details are to be recorded in the designated format for that discipline.
